title: As an author, what do you always do? - Quora

response.answer_text: I always listen to my characters. And if I can’t convince them to do what I want, I let them do what THEY want, and so far the results have been excellent. Some of the most memorable secondary characters in my Peryton series had what I planned to be ‘spear carrier’ roles: like in a cartoon opera, march in, ground your spear, say what i taught you to say, then turn around and walk out. Instead, they marched in, grounded their spears, said what I told them to say… but then looked around, thought for a moment, sat down on the nearest chair or bench, crossed one ankle over the other knee, laid the spear across their lap, looked me square in the eye, and said, “I like it here and I’m not leaving. So deal with me.” I had no choice; they would not negotiate and could not be bullied or shamed into leaving. And what great characters they became! (Yes, Melanthus, I’m looking particularly at you.)

Write. Doesn’t matter what schedule I do it on, whether I can do it every day or not, the most important thing is sitting down and writing. Yes, I plan. Yes, I research. But writing is the only absolute must-do for any writer. I know very successful writers who aren’t on social media, don’t attend conferences or conventions, don’t do book tours, don’t promote. But they all write. Maybe some write fast, some slow, some every few years … but again: it comes down to having put in the work.

I treat my writing like a business because it is. I have regular hours and I schedule my work to meet work goals. I have a Statement of Work that I give to my clients, a drafted NDA, and a contract should they need those, too. My work is scheduled two months out, but I’m always on the look-out for new clients. I am fully prepared to show people what I’ve achieved and what they can expect from me. My clients are welcome to look at the workbook on which I create their stories, including written chapters. In short, they know what to expect from me.

Two things: I always do way, way, way more research than I will ever need, before I ever sit down at my laptop and … I need to write the perfect first sentence before I allow myself to proceed into the rest of the story
